articles.headline: If a Law Bars Asking Your Past Salary, Does It Help or Hurt?
articles.snippet: A growing number of state and local laws ban an employer practice that is said to perpetuate pay bias. But some researchers say the move may be counterproductive.
articles.abstract: A growing number of state and local laws ban an employer practice that is said to perpetuate pay bias. But some researchers say the move may be counterproductive.
articles.lead_paragraph: Laws prohibiting employers from asking job candidates about their past compensation before making a salary offer are gaining momentum, aimed at reducing pay disparities and other obstacles confronting women and minorities.

articles.headline: Trump Administration Proposes Stiff Penalties on Steel and Aluminum Imports
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department said foreign metals posed a threat to national security, setting the stage for President Trump to consider stiff tariffs.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department said foreign metals posed a threat to national security, setting the stage for President Trump to consider stiff tariffs.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration for the first time declared imports of steel and aluminum from China and other nations a threat to national security, laying the foundation for President Trump to impose the types of punitive tariffs he has long championed.

articles.headline: F.B.I. Was Warned of Florida Suspect’s Desire to Kill but Did Not Act
articles.snippet: The information should have been assessed and forwarded to the F.B.I. field office, the agency said.
articles.abstract: The information should have been assessed and forwarded to the F.B.I. field office, the agency said.
articles.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. received a tip last month from someone close to Nikolas Cruz that he owned a gun and had talked of committing a school shooting, the bureau revealed Friday, but it acknowledged that it had failed to investigate.
articles.byline: By Katie Benner, Patricia Mazzei and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: Is It ‘Natural’? Consumers, and Lawyers, Want to Know
articles.snippet: When products are labeled natural, the court challenges begin, raising questions about whether labeling is really misleading or simply fodder for a lawsuit.
articles.abstract: When products are labeled natural, the court challenges begin, raising questions about whether labeling is really misleading or simply fodder for a lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: In recent years, one bright spot in an otherwise lackluster market for packaged foods, beverages and consumer products has been merchandise promoted as “natural.”

articles.headline: 13 Russians Indicted as Mueller Reveals Effort to Aid Trump Campaign
articles.snippet: The indictment does not allege collusion but reveals in painstaking detail how Russians posed as American activists to boost Mr. Trump’s campaign.
articles.abstract: The indictment does not allege collusion but reveals in painstaking detail how Russians posed as American activists to boost Mr. Trump’s campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department charged 13 Russians and three companies on Friday in a sprawling indictment that unveiled a sophisticated network designed to subvert the 2016 election and to support the Trump campaign. It stretched from an office in St. Petersburg, Russia, into the social feeds of Americans and ultimately reached the streets of election battleground states.
articles.byline: By Matt Apuzzo and Sharon LaFraniere

articles.headline: Yevgeny Prigozhin, Russian Oligarch Indicted by U.S., Is Known as ‘Putin’s Cook’
articles.snippet: The secretive oligarch is one of 13 Russians the special counsel charged on Friday for allegedly meddling in the 2016 U.S. election.
articles.abstract: The secretive oligarch is one of 13 Russians the special counsel charged on Friday for allegedly meddling in the 2016 U.S. election.
articles.lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — Long before he was indicted by the United States in a case involving the troll factory that spearheaded Russian efforts to meddle in the 2016 United States elections, Yevgeny V. Prigozhin emerged from prison just as the Soviet Union was collapsing and opened a hot-dog stand.

articles.headline: A ‘Mass Shooting Generation’ Cries Out for Change
articles.snippet: When a gunman killed 17 people this week at Stoneman Douglas High in Florida, the first response of many classmates was not to grieve in silence, but to speak out.
articles.abstract: When a gunman killed 17 people this week at Stoneman Douglas High in Florida, the first response of many classmates was not to grieve in silence, but to speak out.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — Delaney Tarr, a high school senior, cannot remember a time when she did not know about school shootings.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch, Patricia Mazzei and Jack Healy

articles.headline: Inside a 3-Year Russian Campaign to Influence U.S. Voters
articles.snippet: Using American bank accounts, drivers’ licenses and disposable phones, about 80 Russians worked to disparage Hillary Clinton, promote Donald Trump and sow discord.
articles.abstract: Using American bank accounts, drivers’ licenses and disposable phones, about 80 Russians worked to disparage Hillary Clinton, promote Donald Trump and sow discord.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In September, as the first detailed evidence surfaced of Russia’s hijacking of social media in the 2016 election, Irina V. Kaverzina, one of about 80 Russians working on the project in St. Petersburg, emailed a family member with some news.
articles.byline: By Scott Shane and Mark Mazzetti

articles.headline: Christopher Bailey Takes a Final Walk Down the Burberry Runway
articles.snippet: Mr. Bailey is leaving the company he led as both chief designer and C.E.O. A new management team now has to revive the brand’s critical and financial fortunes.
articles.abstract: Mr. Bailey is leaving the company he led as both chief designer and C.E.O. A new management team now has to revive the brand’s critical and financial fortunes.
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — In a mahogany-paneled corner of the palatial Burberry flagship store on Regent Street, Christopher Bailey, the outgoing president and chief creative officer of Britain’s largest luxury brand, sat smiling at a corner table, shrouded in shadows.

articles.headline: The WeWork Manifesto: First, Office Space. Next, the World.
articles.snippet: The brash, ambitious founders of WeWork, a global network of shared office spaces, want nothing less than to transform the way we work, live and play.
articles.abstract: The brash, ambitious founders of WeWork, a global network of shared office spaces, want nothing less than to transform the way we work, live and play.
articles.lead_paragraph: On a cold February morning at the Brooklyn Navy Yard, the skeleton of a modern 15-story building was rising from a muddy construction site along the East River. As long and as tall as a cruise ship, the sleek glass structure loomed above rusty, century-old dry docks, serving notice to the industrial neighborhood that the new economy was coming.

articles.headline: Trump’s Conspicuous Silence Leaves a Struggle Against Russia Without a Leader
articles.snippet: President Trump depicted indictments charging Russians with interfering in America’s politics as a vindication for himself rather than a threat to the United States.
articles.abstract: President Trump depicted indictments charging Russians with interfering in America’s politics as a vindication for himself rather than a threat to the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After more than a dozen Russians and three companies were indicted on Friday for interfering in the 2016 elections, President Trump’s first reaction was to claim personal vindication: “The Trump campaign did nothing wrong — no collusion!” he wrote on Twitter.

articles.headline: To Stir Discord in 2016, Russians Turned Most Often to Facebook
articles.snippet: The special counsel’s indictment detailed how crucial Facebook and Instagram were to the Russian campaign to disrupt the presidential election.
articles.abstract: The special counsel’s indictment detailed how crucial Facebook and Instagram were to the Russian campaign to disrupt the presidential election.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — In 2014, Russians working for a shadowy firm called the Internet Research Agency started gathering American followers in online groups focused on issues like religion and immigration. Around mid-2015, the Russians began buying digital ads to spread their messages. A year later, they tapped their followers to help organize political rallies across the United States.
articles.byline: By Sheera Frenkel and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Florida Agency Investigated Nikolas Cruz After Violent Social Media Posts
articles.snippet: After visiting and questioning Mr. Cruz at his home in 2016, the Department of Children and Families determined he was not a risk to himself or others.
articles.abstract: After visiting and questioning Mr. Cruz at his home in 2016, the Department of Children and Families determined he was not a risk to himself or others.
articles.lead_paragraph: PARKLAND, Fla. — A Florida social services agency conducted an in-home investigation of Nikolas Cruz after he exhibited troubling behavior nearly a year and a half before he shot and killed 17 people at his former high school in Florida, a state report shows.
articles.byline: By Audra D. S. Burch, Frances Robles and Patricia Mazzei

articles.headline: President or Luxury Towers: Either Way, Trump Is the Rage in India
articles.snippet: President Trump’s eldest son is headed to India on a sales trip for the family’s real estate business. Indians are star-struck by a family both rich and famous.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s eldest son is headed to India on a sales trip for the family’s real estate business. Indians are star-struck by a family both rich and famous.
articles.lead_paragraph: GURGAON, India — When the Trump family jet lands in India this week, the family member taking a tour of the world’s largest democracy — with a Secret Service detail in tow — won’t be the president on a diplomatic mission. It will be his eldest son, Donald Trump Jr., on a sales trip.
articles.byline: By Maria Abi-Habib and Eric Lipton

articles.headline: Trump’s Evolution From Relief to Fury Over the Russia Indictment
articles.snippet: The president unleashed a two-day Twitter tirade that was unusually angry and defiant even by his standards.
articles.abstract: The president unleashed a two-day Twitter tirade that was unusually angry and defiant even by his standards.
articles.lead_paragraph: WEST PALM BEACH, Fla. — President Trump began the weekend believing that something good had just happened to him. An indictment leveled against 13 Russians for interfering with the 2016 election had not accused him or anyone around him of wrongdoing. “No collusion” was his refrain.
articles.byline: By Katie Rogers and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Bitcoin Thieves Threaten Real Violence for Virtual Currencies
articles.snippet: Criminals have been going after big holders of Bitcoin and Ether, taking advantage of the ease with which vast virtual currency riches can be transferred.
articles.abstract: Criminals have been going after big holders of Bitcoin and Ether, taking advantage of the ease with which vast virtual currency riches can be transferred.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The currency they were after was virtual, but the guns they carried were anything but.

articles.headline: What Makes Public Radio ‘Very Personal’ Magnifies Its #MeToo Cases
articles.snippet: Public broadcasting, which fosters an intimate relationship with its listeners and counts on their donations, is scrambling after the ouster of prominent figures over allegations of misbehavior.
articles.abstract: Public broadcasting, which fosters an intimate relationship with its listeners and counts on their donations, is scrambling after the ouster of prominent figures over allegations of misbehavior.
articles.lead_paragraph: Of all the realms of media that have been shaken by the #MeToo movement, perhaps the most surprising has been public radio, the home of virtuous journalism and thoughtful, warm-voiced commentary.

articles.headline: For Parents of Shooting Victims, a Support Network That Keeps Growing
articles.snippet: Those who have lost children in earlier tragedies will reach out to the newest grieving parents to console, advise and often recruit them to the gun control cause.
articles.abstract: Those who have lost children in earlier tragedies will reach out to the newest grieving parents to console, advise and often recruit them to the gun control cause.
articles.lead_paragraph: A child is shot to death. Maybe at school, maybe at the movies. It is all over TV, all over Twitter, just like the last mass shooting.

articles.headline: 1.5 Million Retirees Await Congressional Fix for a Pension Time Bomb
articles.snippet: The agreement to increase government spending reached this month included a deal to craft what could effectively be a federal rescue for pension plans.
articles.abstract: The agreement to increase government spending reached this month included a deal to craft what could effectively be a federal rescue for pension plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The sprawling agreement to boost government spending reached by Republicans and Democrats this month quietly included a step toward defusing what could be a financial time bomb for 1.5 million retirees and hundreds of companies in the industrial Midwest and the South.
articles.byline: By Jim Tankersley and Alan Rappeport

articles.headline: Google Chrome Now Blocks Irksome Ads. That’s a Good Thing, Right?
articles.snippet: The brower’s latest update filters out pop-up ads and other annoyances. It also strengthens Google’s grip on the web.
articles.abstract: The brower’s latest update filters out pop-up ads and other annoyances. It also strengthens Google’s grip on the web.
articles.lead_paragraph: As advertising has become more intrusive in recent years, hundreds of millions of web users have installed ad-blocking software to ward off full-page pop-ups, blaring video pitches that start automatically and large ads with unstoppable countdown clocks that obscure the content you actually want to see.

articles.headline: How Unwitting Americans Encountered Russian Operatives Online
articles.snippet: With imperfect English and tireless posting on Facebook and Twitter, Russian trolls summoned Americans to rallies, praised Donald J. Trump and played on political divisions.
articles.abstract: With imperfect English and tireless posting on Facebook and Twitter, Russian trolls summoned Americans to rallies, praised Donald J. Trump and played on political divisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: They were politically active Americans scattered around the country, dedicating their spare time to the 2016 presidential campaign or various causes. And the seeming fellow activists who called them to rallies via Facebook, or joined in the free-for-all on Twitter, appeared unremarkable.

articles.headline: Tools of Trump’s Fixer: Payouts, Intimidation and the Tabloids
articles.snippet: Beyond facilitating a $130,000 payment to silence a pornographic film actress, Donald Trump’s lawyer spent years making aggressive behind-the-scenes efforts to protect him.
articles.abstract: Beyond facilitating a $130,000 payment to silence a pornographic film actress, Donald Trump’s lawyer spent years making aggressive behind-the-scenes efforts to protect him.
articles.lead_paragraph: As accounts of past sexual indiscretions threatened to surface during Donald J. Trump’s presidential campaign, the job of stifling potentially damaging stories fell to his longtime lawyer and all-around fixer, Michael D. Cohen.
articles.byline: By Jim Rutenberg, Megan Twohey, Rebecca R. Ruiz, Mike McIntire and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Iran, Deeply Embedded in Syria, Expands ‘Axis of Resistance’
articles.snippet: Iran is training thousands of militiamen in Syria and deploying drones and precision weapons. Its goal, say analysts: a united front in any war with Israel.
articles.abstract: Iran is training thousands of militiamen in Syria and deploying drones and precision weapons. Its goal, say analysts: a united front in any war with Israel.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — When an Iranian drone flew into Israeli airspace this month, it set off a rapid series of strikes and counterstrikes that deepened fears over whether a new, catastrophic war was brewing in the Middle East.
articles.byline: By Ben Hubbard, Isabel Kershner and Anne Barnard

articles.headline: The C.E.O. Who Stood Up to President Trump: Ken Frazier Speaks Out
articles.snippet: The head of Merck quit Mr. Trump’s business council after racial violence in Virginia, saying “as a matter of my own personal conscience, I could not remain.”
articles.abstract: The head of Merck quit Mr. Trump’s business council after racial violence in Virginia, saying “as a matter of my own personal conscience, I could not remain.”
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the nation’s most powerful black chief executives is breaking his silence after publicly sparring with President Trump last year.
